evidence.dc:description:
"We found that GATAD1 pS102 interacted with 14-3-3ε with a binding constant of about 3 μM
(Fig. 5A). This interaction strictly depends on the phosphorylation of S102: Neither the non-phosphorylated wild-type peptide nor the peptide with the disease-linked S102P mutation showed detectable binding(Fig. 5A). Importantly, the ITC data also showed that the phosphomimetic S102D and S102E mutant peptides do not interact with 14-3-3ε (Fig. 5A)."

dc:source.dc:abstract: Despite their lack of a defined 3D structure, intrinsically disordered regions (IDRs) of proteins play important biological roles. Many IDRs contain short linear motifs (SLiMs) that mediate protein-protein interactions (PPIs), which can be regulated by post-translational modifications like phosphorylation. 20% of pathogenic missense mutations are found in IDRs, and understanding how such mutations affect PPIs is essential for unraveling disease mechanisms. Here, we employ peptide-based interaction proteomics to investigate 36 disease-associated mutations affecting phosphorylation sites. Our results unveil significant differences in interactomes between phosphorylated and non-phosphorylated peptides, often due to disrupted phosphorylation-dependent SLiMs. We focused on a mutation of a serine phosphorylation site in the transcription factor GATAD1, which causes dilated cardiomyopathy. We find that this phosphorylation site mediates interaction with 14-3-3 family proteins. Follow-up experiments reveal the structural basis of this interaction and suggest that 14-3-3 binding affects GATAD1 nucleocytoplasmic transport by masking a nuclear localisation signal. Our results demonstrate that pathogenic mutations of human phosphorylation sites can significantly impact protein-protein interactions, offering insights into potential molecular mechanisms underlying pathogenesis.
dc:source.dc:creator: Rrustemi T
dc:source.dc:title: Pathogenic mutations of human phosphorylation sites affect protein-protein interactions.

evidence.rdfs:label: isothermal titration calorimetry and 14-3-3 proteins

evidence.dc:description: The group of proteins (14-3-3) which this protein-protein interaction focuses on have not definitively been implicated in cardiomyopathy.

The two 14-3-3ε proteins in the asymmetric unit (ASU) of the
crystals formed a two-fold symmetric homodimer, which is typical for
the 14-3-3 protein family. Eachmonomer consists of nine α-helices and
harbors one phosphorylated GATAD1 peptide in a binding groove
formed by helices α3, α5, α7, and α9 (Fig. 5D).
evidence.rdfs:label: X-ray crystallography

evidence.dc:description: YWHAE is not definitively associated with cardiomyopathy

Immunohistochemistry staining for an antibody against GATAD1 is abnormal in patients who are homozygous for the variant in GATAD1 compared to controls and an individual with DCM due to a pathogenic variant in TPM1.

dc:source.dc:abstract: Dilated cardiomyopathy (DCM) is a heritable, genetically heterogeneous disorder that typically exhibits autosomal dominant inheritance. Genomic strategies enable discovery of novel, unsuspected molecular underpinnings of familial DCM. We performed genome-wide mapping and exome sequencing in a unique family wherein DCM segregated as an autosomal recessive (AR) trait.
dc:source.dc:creator: Theis JL
dc:source.dc:title: Homozygosity mapping and exome sequencing reveal GATAD1 mutation in autosomal recessive dilated cardiomyopathy.

evidence.rdfs:label: GATAD1 Immunohistochemistry in Proband

evidence.dc:description: With updated SOP, now counted as case-level data

"The phosphorylated GATAD1 peptide specifically interacts with the
multiple 14-3-3 protein family members, despite lacking an annotated 14-3-3
binding motif."
evidence.rdfs:label: PRISMA Screen

evidence.dc:description: 14-3-3 family of proteins has not been definitively implicated in cardiomyopathy
Within healthy left ventricular tissue, GATAD1 localized to the nucleus and cytoplasm with a homogenous, striated staining pattern
evidence.rdfs:label: Immunohistochemistry Expression in Healthy Myocardium

evidence.dc:description: Using RT-PCR the authors demonstrated GATAD1 is expressed in mainly the heart and brain. In embryonic fish the expression was significantly higher in the cardiac tissue compared to adult fish. Using a GFP-tagged protein, the authors confirmed the protein was expressed in the heart.

dc:source.dc:abstract: Animal models have played a critical role in validating human dilated cardiomyopathy (DCM) genes, particularly those that implicate novel mechanisms for heart failure. However, the disease phenotype may be delayed due to age-dependent penetrance. For this reason, we generated an adult zebrafish model, which is a simpler vertebrate model with higher throughput than rodents. Specifically, we studied the zebrafish homologue of GATAD1, a recently identified gene for adult-onset autosomal recessive DCM. We showed cardiac expression of gatad1 transcripts, by whole mount in situ hybridization in zebrafish embryos, and demonstrated nuclear and sarcomeric I-band subcellular localization of Gatad1 protein in cardiomyocytes, by injecting a Tol2 plasmid encoding fluorescently-tagged Gatad1. We next generated gatad1 knock-out fish lines by TALEN technology and a transgenic fish line that expresses the human DCM GATAD1-S102P mutation in cardiomyocytes. Under stress conditions, longitudinal studies uncovered heart failure (HF)-like phenotypes in stable KO mutants and a tendency toward HF phenotypes in transgenic lines. Based on these efforts of studying a gene-based inherited cardiomyopathy model, we discuss the strengths and bottlenecks of adult zebrafish as a new vertebrate model for assessing candidate cardiomyopathy genes.
dc:source.dc:creator: Yang J
dc:source.dc:title: Modeling GATAD1-Associated Dilated Cardiomyopathy in Adult Zebrafish.

evidence.rdfs:label: Zebra fish Expression

evidence.dc:description: FLAG immunoprecipitation showed protein interaction with HAT1, RBBP4, PHF12, RBBP7, KDM5A, SIN3B
evidence.rdfs:label: FLAG Immunoprecipitation

evidence.dc:description: Proteins with proven interaction have not been shown to cause cardiomyopathy

The mutant zebrafish survived to adulthood without any signs of heart failure until the authors imposed stress by feeding a 4% cholesterol diet. The fish then started to show reduced swimming capacity consistent with exercise intolerance seen in humans with heart failure. The authors then treated the fish with 0.3% ethanol. This decreased survival and was associated with enlarged hearts.
evidence.rdfs:label: Zebra fish model

evidence.dc:description:
The zebrafish with the mutant alleles only developed a phenotype consistent with heart failure when exposed to stressors (high cholesterol and ethanol).

Based on the group discussion we decided that given that there is only one paper using model organisms, the points should be reduced until another paper can confirm these findings.

Some fish (1/6) with the mutant allele did develop an enlarged heart which would be consistent with dilated cardiomyopathy. The fish with the mutant allele started to die around 13 months compared to the fish with the wild type allele which started to die around 20 months. The authors do not comment on the cause of premature death. It could be related to cardiac function.
evidence.rdfs:label: Zebra fish model p.Ser102Pro

evidence.dc:description:
Only 1 out of 6 transgenic fish with the mutant allele developed a significantly increased heart size.

Based on the group discussion we decided that given that there is only one paper using model organisms, the points should be reduced until another paper can confirm these findings.
Immunohistochemistry demonstrated nuclear localization of GATAD1 in left ventricular myocytes, yet subcellular expression and nuclear morphology were aberrant in the proband.
Reduced based on specifications document recommending missense homozygous variants from consanguineous families are reduced by 0.5.

dc:description: GATAD1 was evaluated for autosomal recessive dilated cardiomyopathy (DCM). GATAD1 was originally evaluated for DCM by the ClinGen DCM GCEP on September 27, 2019. Evidence of the association of this gene with DCM was re-evaluated using SOP v10 on June 28, 2024. As a result, the classification did not change. A summary of the information contributing to the classification of this gene at the time of re-evaluation is summarized herein. Human genetic evidence supporting this gene-disease relationship includes case-level data and segregation data. The human genetic level evidence remains limited to one paper (Theis et al, 2011, PMID: 21965549) which reports on a consanguineous family with adult-onset DCM. A homozygous missense variant in GATAD1 was reported in three affected siblings. Segregation data gave a LOD score of 3.1. In addition, this gene-disease assertion is supported by animal models and expression studies. The missense variant reported by Theis et al (2011, PMID 21965549) was shown to affect expression in cardiac tissue. Yang et al (2016, PMID: 28955713) report on a knockout zebrafish model and a model with the missense variant previously reported. The knockout zebrafish only developed a phenotype consistent with DCM when exposed to stressors, and only 1 out of 6 transgenic fish with the mutant allele developed a significantly increased heart size. In summary, there is limited evidence to support this gene-disease relationship. More evidence is needed to support the relationship of GATAD1 with autosomal recessive DCM. This classification was approved by the ClinGen Dilated Cardiomyopathy Working Group June 28, 2024 (SOP Version 10).
